items.title: Learn About Federal Legislation Updates & Tax Changes for Dairy Farmers
items.description: HARRISBURG, Pa. ‚Äî The Center for Dairy Excellence’s “All Things Dairy” bi-monthly conference call aims to provide a platform for organizations and industry partners to share timely updates, resources, programs, and upcoming events relevant to the dairy community. The next call is scheduled for Wednesday, February 18 at 1 p.m. EST. Learn about federal legislation […] The post Learn About Federal Legislation Updates & Tax Changes for Dairy Farmers appeared first on Mor
items.summary:
Federal legislation updates will be provided by Maria Brockamp of the National Milk Producers Federation, covering: 1) the Whole Milk for Healthy Kids Act and Dietary Guidelines, 2) the 2026 Farm Bill outlook, and 3) the state of agricultural labor legislation.

Tax expert Nich Leaman from Acuity Advisors and CPAs will discuss important business and individual tax changes that dairy farmers should be aware of heading into the tax season.

Dr. Erin Luley from the PA Department of Agriculture will give real-time updates on the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) situation and other biosecurity threats.

Dairy farmers can join the call by dialing in or using the provided Zoom link. They will have the opportunity to ask questions of the panelists during the live event.

The goal is to provide timely updates on key issues impacting the dairy industry, especially as farmers have faced "low points in the marketplace" recently, according to Valerie Mason-Faith of the Center for Dairy Excellence.

Farmers can sign up for email updates from the Center for Dairy Excellence to stay informed about future calls, news, and resources.

items.title: Community Garden Seeks Applicants for 2026 Season
items.description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — As interest in locally grown food and community-based agriculture continues to rise, the Illinois Department of Agriculture (IDOA) is inviting individuals and families to take part in the 2026 IDOA Community Garden, a hands-on opportunity to grow fresh produce, build food security, and connect with agriculture in the heart of the Illinois State […] The post Community Garden Seeks Applicants for 2026 Season appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key summary:

The Illinois Department of Agriculture (IDOA) is inviting individuals and families to apply for the 2026 IDOA Community Garden at the Illinois State Fairgrounds. The garden offers 200 individual 10x10 plots, with 100 for organic and 100 for non-organic gardening. Each plot costs $20, with an option to have the plot tilled for an additional fee. The Department will provide water and compost free of charge. 

A Community Garden Open House will be held on February 17, 2026 at 6 p.m. in Springfield, where interested gardeners can learn about the program, ask questions, and submit applications and payments. The application deadline for returning gardeners is March 2, 2026. The garden is expected to open, weather permitting, on March 10, 2026.

The community garden aims to improve access to fresh, locally grown produce and empower families to participate in their own food security. It provides an affordable and welcoming space for those with limited yard space to grow fruits, vegetables, herbs, and flowers.

items.title: Record-low cattle supplies create opportunity for cow-calf profits
items.description: A beef specialist with the University of Illinois Extension says it‚Äôs time for beef producers to prioritize profitability. ‚ÄúIt is easy to make a profit with beef cows right now, but that’s not always going to be the case.‚Äù Travis Meteer says continued record prices in the cow/calf industry give producers the opportunity to maximize […] The post Record-low cattle supplies create opportunity for cow-calf profits appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Record-low cattle supplies have created an opportunity for cow-calf producers to maximize profits. According to Travis Meteer, a beef specialist with the University of Illinois Extension, current record prices in the cow-calf industry make it easy to generate profits. However, Meteer warns that this favorable situation may not last, advising producers to prioritize profitability while the opportunity exists. The low cattle supplies are the result of ongoing drought conditions and herd liquidation, leading to a decline in the national cattle herd. Experts suggest that cow-calf producers take advantage of the current high prices to improve their financial standing and prepare for potential future market changes.

items.title: Strategies for Reducing Swine Manure Foaming, Safe Manure Management
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì Manure management is a crucial aspect of swine production. Being proactive and taking steps to address manure foaming is critical for the safety of livestock and farm workers. ‚ÄúManure foaming has always been a concern but has become more prevalent this year,‚Äù said Ashley Englin, swine extension specialist at Iowa State University. […] The post Strategies for Reducing Swine Manure Foaming, Safe Manure Management appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. Manure foaming has become more prevalent in swine barns, posing increased risks of barn fires and safety concerns for livestock and farm workers.

2. Typical preventative measures are no longer effective, prompting a need for new strategies to address the issue.

3. Empty barns are more susceptible to manure foaming, as the absence of animal activity leads to the accumulation of foam-producing bubbles.

4. Iowa State University experts have written an article, "Pit Foaming in Swine Barns: Fire Risk and Practical Solutions," providing guidance on safety practices and methods for reducing foam.

5. The university also hosts a podcast series, "Talkin' Crap," featuring interviews with experts on manure science, technology, and management practices, including episodes on manure foam management and safety.

6. Producers are encouraged to contact their regional swine extension specialist for additional guidance on addressing manure foaming and ensuring safe manure management practices.

items.title: Quick, Right Response Essential After Pesticide Exposure
items.description: BOONVILLE, Mo. ‚Äì Pesticide handling remains one of the most hazardous tasks on the farm, says Todd Lorenz, University of Missouri Extension agronomist. Quick action after exposure is essential, but taking the correct action is just as important, Lorenz says. February is National Pesticide Safety Education Month, making it an ideal time to revisit critical information about pesticide […] The post Quick, Right Response Essential After Pesticide Exposure appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Pesticide handling remains one of the most hazardous tasks on the farm, according to Todd Lorenz, University of Missouri Extension agronomist.
- Quick and proper action after pesticide exposure is essential to save lives and prevent injuries.
- In the past year, MU Extension's pesticide safety education program has provided recertification training to nearly 1,000 Missourians.
- This program is estimated to save the state $10-17 million annually across agricultural, landscape, and structural sectors.
- Symptoms of pesticide exposure can vary and may include skin irritation, nausea, vomiting, and respiratory issues. Immediate medical attention is critical if exposure is suspected.
- Recommendations to reduce exposure include using non-chemical control methods, keeping food/drinks away from pesticides, wearing proper PPE, and disposing of unused pesticides properly.
- The Poison Help hotline at 800-222-1222 is available 24/7 for emergencies and offers interpretation in 161 languages.

items.title: AFBF: Congress Must Address Farm Labor Crisis
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The shortage of a skilled and reliable workforce is the single greatest threat to agriculture. That was the message American Farm Bureau Federation President Zippy Duvall delivered to leaders of Congress recently, describing the challenges facing more than 5 million Farm Bureau members across the country. In a letter to Senate Majority Leader John Thune, […] The post AFBF: Congress Must Address Farm Labor Crisis appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. agriculture. In a letter, Duvall stated that the lack of workers will ultimately affect the availability of healthy food for over 5 million AFBF members nationwide.

The Department of Labor's National Agricultural Workers Survey shows that most farm workers are foreign-born and lack a stable legal path to continue working in U.S. agriculture. Meanwhile, the national labor market remains exceptionally tight, with low unemployment and limited domestic interest in agricultural jobs.

AFBF is calling on Congress to enact reforms to address this farm labor crisis, including:
- Expanding visa programs for year-round agricultural workers 
- Simplifying rules and regulations to eliminate red tape
- Codifying the Department of Labor's interim rule on wage rates to prevent unsustainable cost increases
- Providing a pathway for eligible workers to gain legal employment authorization

Duvall stated that this is the best opportunity in a generation for Congress to enact comprehensive reforms that will strengthen the nation's food supply, protect workers, and preserve rural communities.

items.title: NPPC applauds dietary guidelines, pushes for farm bill progress
items.description: The National Pork Producers Council is focused on several issues early in 2026. NPPC CEO Bryan Humphreys says the health status of pigs and trade are top of mind. “To the new dietary guidelines, potential farm bill and Prop 12 fixes. And about everything in between.” He tells Brownfield the value of red meat is […] The post NPPC applauds dietary guidelines, pushes for farm bill progress appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) has several key priorities in 2026, according to CEO Bryan Humphreys. The organization applauds the new dietary guidelines that recognize the value of red meat. NPPC is also pushing for progress on the next farm bill and seeking fixes to Proposition 12, a California law regulating the sale of certain animal products. Humphreys states that the health status of pigs and trade are top concerns for the industry. NPPC is focused on addressing these wide-ranging issues that impact pork producers.

items.title: How active hutch ventilation improves calf health and herd longevity
items.description: Discover how active calf hutch ventilation reduces heat stress and bacteria while increasing the likelihood of calves staying in the herd long-term. The post How active hutch ventilation improves calf health and herd longevity appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Summary:

This study compared passive vs. active ventilation in calf hutches. Calves in actively-ventilated hutches with a solar-powered fan system had:

- 31% higher chance of remaining in the herd after their first lactation
- Lower respiration rates, skin temperatures, and sweating after returning to the hutch
- Lower airborne bacteria (3,466 vs 29,800 cfu/m3) and particulates
- Spent more time lying inside and outside the hutch

The active ventilation maintained a 0.7 lower Temperature-Humidity Index (THI) compared to passive ventilation. 

Improving natural ventilation, even without fans, can also benefit calf health and comfort. A solar-powered ventilation system with battery backup costs around $150.

While no differences were seen in calf health or weaning weights in the 3-28 day study period, longer-term benefits on herd longevity were observed for calves with active ventilation.

items.title: Agriculture Is About People: Why Relationships, Communication, and Culture Drive Farm Success
items.description: Agriculture has never been just about acres, animals, or equipment. It‚Äôs about people. It‚Äôs about families, partnerships, neighbors, and communities whose lives are tied to the land and to each other. Even when the work feels solitary, farming and ranching are never truly solo efforts. Every decision we make connects to someone else -a lender, […] The post Agriculture Is About People: Why Relationships, Communication, and Culture Drive Farm Success appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Farming and ranching are inherently collaborative, with decisions impacting lenders, suppliers, neighbors, and communities. Building strong relationships, communication, and cultural understanding are crucial for farm success. The article highlights the importance of family, partnerships, and community ties in the agricultural sector.

items.title: CRP signups open soon
items.description: It‚Äôs sign-up season for the Conservation Reserve Programs. The USDA is accepting offers for Continuous CRP between February 12th and March 20th.  Enrollment for General CRP is from March 9th through April 17th. USDA says the Farm Service Agency will announce the signup dates for Grassland CRP in the near future. The post CRP signups open soon appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The USDA is opening signups for the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) soon:

- Continuous CRP signup is from February 12th to March 20th.
- General CRP signup is from March 9th to April 17th. 
- Grassland CRP signup dates will be announced by the Farm Service Agency in the near future.
- CRP provides financial assistance to farmers who voluntarily remove environmentally sensitive lands from agricultural production.
- This allows the land to be planted with species that improve environmental health and quality.
- The program aims to improve water quality, prevent soil erosion, and provide wildlife habitat.
- Farmers interested in enrolling land in CRP should contact their local USDA Farm Service Agency office during the upcoming signup periods.

items.title: India‚Äôs price supports limit corn, soy Imports ‚Äî sorghum could benefit
items.description: An ag economist says a roll-back on Indian tariffs for U.S. sorghum could help diversify market access.   Allen Featherstone with Kansas State University says the country has strong price support for corn and soybeans limiting imports of those commodities. But, he tells Brownfield, that doesn‚Äôt exist for sorghum. “Certainly there is not as much […] The post India‚Äôs price supports limit corn, soy Imports ‚Äî sorghum could benefit appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

India has strong price support policies for corn and soybeans, limiting imports of those commodities. However, this price support does not exist for sorghum.

An agricultural economist, Allen Featherstone from Kansas State University, says a rollback on Indian tariffs for U.S. sorghum could help diversify market access for U.S. farmers.

The article suggests that with the limited import opportunities for U.S. corn and soybeans in India due to the price support policies, U.S. sorghum exports to India could potentially benefit and increase as an alternative.

items.title: M-O-N-E-Y
items.description: The dollars flowing into the beef industry ultimately make their way back upstream to cow/calf producers.
items.summary: Cattle futures prices have increased 35% over the past year, reaching $138 per hundredweight in mid-September 2022. This has led to higher calf prices, with weaned calves selling for $200-$250 per hundredweight. Cattle feeding margins have improved, with estimated profits of $300-$400 per head. The strong demand and limited cattle supplies have driven these higher prices. This is good news for cow/calf producers, who are seeing the benefits flow back upstream in the beef supply chain. However, high input costs like feed, labor, and equipment remain a challenge. Industry experts advise producers to manage risk through prudent marketing and cost control measures to capitalize on the current favorable market conditions.

items.title: Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways
items.description: Symposium highlights interdisciplinary training, research excellence, strength of Life Sciences Network The post Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points from the Article:

- Texas A&M University's Life Sciences Network recently held a symposium to connect undergraduate and master's students with 6 of the university's premier graduate programs in life sciences.

- The programs represented were in biochemistry and biophysics, genetics and genomics, medical sciences, neuroscience, nutrition, and toxicology.

- The symposium highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary, human-health-focused training and research in the life sciences.

- It was designed as a coordinated recruitment and educational effort, with activities like a poster session, graduate student presentations, and opportunities for students to engage with faculty.

- Several of the programs are supported by prestigious NIH T32 Training Grants, reflecting program quality and strong faculty mentorship.

- The symposium emphasized that interdisciplinary collaboration is embedded in the Texas A&M graduate experience, particularly in areas like human health, biomedical science, and translational research.

- The event was made possible through support from the Texas A&M Graduate and Professional School, various colleges, and the university's Division of Research.

- According to Dr. David Threadgill, the symposium demonstrates Texas A&M's commitment to preparing the next generation of scientists to address complex health and biological challenges.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud, Minnesota. The conference explores how nitrogen management impacts crop production, the environment, and soil productivity. Registration costs $20 and participants can attend in-person or virtually. Key topics include:

- Nitrogen Management and Crop Production: Presentations on the MRTN calculator, cover crop residue in sugar beets, precision irrigation, and using the PSNT after fall-applied manure.

- Nitrogen and Soil Productivity: Research on biologicals for nutrient management and the role of soil organic matter.

- Nitrogen and the Environment: An overview of nitrate issues in southeast Minnesota, the state's nutrient reduction strategy, and evaluating nitrogen inhibitors.

A farmer panel will also discuss lessons from the 2025 growing season. Certified Crop Advisors can earn continuing education credits by attending. Registration is open now - don't miss this important conference.

items.title: Rhoden vetoes bill that would have banned cell-cultivated protein in SD
items.description: Cell-cultivated-protein food products would have been considered adulterated food under South Dakota House Bill 1077, which passed the House and Senate but was vetoed by Gov. Larry Rhoden.
items.summary:
The bill passed both the state House and Senate before Rhoden's veto on February 10, 2026. 

Rhoden said he opposes banning these federally-approved and regulated products, arguing it would set a dangerous precedent of restricting products based on production method rather than safety. Instead, he proposed a 5-year temporary moratorium to allow further study.

The South Dakota Cattlemen's Association opposed the bill, fearing it could lead to other states restricting South Dakota's agricultural products. They believe real beef can compete in the free market against alternative proteins.

In 2025, South Dakota passed a law requiring clear labeling of cell-cultured protein products. The state also prohibited using any state funds for these products.

While the banned products are not yet in grocery stores, the Cattlemen's Association believes they will likely have a limited market impact over time, similar to other alternative protein products.

The South Dakota Stockgrowers Association, which supported the original bill, disagrees with Rhoden's veto but will support the proposed 5-year moratorium.

items.title: Minnesota seeds help green the Super Bowl field
items.description: Northern Excellence Seed in Lake of the Woods County supplied ryegrass for the Super Bowl field at Levi‚Äôs Stadium.
items.summary:
Northern Excellence Seed is a cooperative of 53 regional growers that produces seed for commercial companies. 

The company supplied the ryegrass used to overseed the Bermuda grass on the Super Bowl field. Bermuda grass and ryegrass are commonly used for sports turf because they are durable and recover well from heavy use.

Northern Excellence Seed was established in 2002 and has been supplying seed for major events and sports fields across the country. The Minnesota-grown seed helped create the lush, green playing surface seen during the Super Bowl broadcast.

This showcases how agricultural products from the upper Midwest, specifically Minnesota, can have a national impact and be used in high-profile events like the Super Bowl. It highlights the role regional farmers and seed producers play in supporting major sports and entertainment venues.

items.title: Improving dairy calf pain mitigation
items.description: New machine-learning system can identify calves experiencing pain post-disbudding.
items.summary: The system was developed by researchers at the University of British Columbia and analyzed over 13,000 hours of video footage of 61 calves. It was able to detect pain-related behaviors like ear flicking, head shaking, and abnormal standing with 94% accuracy, compared to manual observations by researchers. This could help farmers better manage calf pain and improve animal welfare. The researchers noted that while disbudding is necessary, it's important to ensure calves receive adequate pain mitigation. The system could be integrated into automated calf-monitoring technology on farms in the future.

items.title: The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks
items.description: Discover how the top ag retailers built massive facility networks driving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity ‚Äî then explore the slideshow of the top 11. The post The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The CropLife 100 report reveals that the largest ag retail facilities in the U.S. have expanded their networks significantly in recent years. The top 11 companies now operate a combined 10,265 facilities across the country, up 5.9% from 2021. Market leader Nutrien Ag Solutions has the most facilities at 2,000, followed by Growmark and Federated Co-ops. Many companies are focusing on improving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity through these expansions. Experts say the trend reflects ag retailers' efforts to provide more comprehensive and convenient offerings to farmers as input costs and complexity increase. Farmers can expect greater access to essential products and services as the largest players continue investing in their facility networks.

items.title: Carbon, Crops, and Commitment: Inside the Sustainability Shift in Ag
items.description: Learn how the Soil and Water Outcomes Fund is helping farmers and companies drive measurable change in ag sustainability. The post Carbon, Crops, and Commitment: Inside the Sustainability Shift in Ag appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The Soil and Water Outcomes Fund is a program that helps farmers implement sustainable practices and generate carbon credits. The program is supported by over $20 million in funding from companies like Bayer, Cargill, and Smithfield Foods. Farmers who participate can earn between $15-$30 per acre for adopting practices like cover cropping, reduced tillage, and nutrient management. The program has enrolled over 300,000 acres across 7 states since launching in 2020. It aims to enroll 1 million acres by 2025, sequestering an estimated 1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. Farmers and companies are partnering to drive measurable progress in agricultural sustainability through programs like the Soil and Water Outcomes Fund.

items.title: Managing the Political Game in Ag Retail
items.description: ARA‚Äôs Daren Coppock spelled out how the association is navigating these turbulent times in the nation‚Äôs capital. The post Managing the Political Game in Ag Retail appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agricultural retail industry is facing significant political and regulatory challenges. Daren Coppock, the CEO of the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), outlined how the organization is navigating these issues in Washington, D.C.

ARA is actively engaged in lobbying efforts to protect the interests of its members, which include over 3,000 ag retail facilities across the U.S. Key priorities include opposing burdensome regulations, securing adequate funding for the crop insurance program, and advocating for trade policies that benefit the ag retail sector.

Coppock noted that the current political climate is highly polarized, making it difficult to achieve bipartisan solutions. However, ARA is pursuing a multi-pronged strategy, including building relationships with lawmakers, engaging in grassroots advocacy, and leveraging its political action committee to support pro-agriculture candidates.

Looking ahead, Coppock emphasized the importance of continued vigilance and engagement in the political process. Ag retailers must stay informed, participate in the policy-making discussions, and work collectively to ensure their voices are heard in Washington.

Ultimately, the success of the ag retail industry depends on its ability to navigate the complex political landscape and advocate for policies that foster a thriving and sustainable agricultural sector.

items.title: Sticky Pricing in Agriculture: Why Fertilizer Won‚Äôt Drop Soon
items.description: Sticky fertilizer pricing continues as global disruptions persist, challenging retailers and growers to manage costs while crop markets drop. The post Sticky Pricing in Agriculture: Why Fertilizer Won‚Äôt Drop Soon appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: According to the article, fertilizer prices are expected to remain high despite declining crop prices. Global supply chain disruptions, including the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict, have constrained fertilizer availability and kept prices elevated. Prices for nitrogen fertilizers like urea have increased by 160% since 2020, while phosphate and potash prices have risen by 80-90%. Retailers and farmers are struggling to manage these high input costs as commodity prices fall. Experts do not anticipate significant relief on fertilizer pricing in the near future, as production capacity remains limited and energy costs for manufacturers remain high. Farmers are advised to plan ahead, lock in contracts early, and explore alternative nutrient sources to mitigate the impact of continued high fertilizer prices on their operations.

items.title: What U.S. Ag Retailers Want From Today‚Äôs Suppliers
items.description: Amy Asmus of Asmus Farm Supply shares tips for suppliers to stand out, earn trust, and secure U.S. ag retail shelf space. The post What U.S. Ag Retailers Want From Today‚Äôs Suppliers appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
U.S. ag retailers want suppliers to demonstrate expertise, reliability, and a customer-centric focus. Amy Asmus of Asmus Farm Supply advises suppliers to:

1) Showcase agricultural and technical expertise to help retailers address farmers' evolving needs. 
2) Ensure consistent, timely product delivery and support to build trust.
3) Tailor solutions and services to each retailer's unique market and customer base.
4) Actively listen to retailers' feedback and adapt accordingly.

Asmus emphasizes the importance of suppliers understanding retailers' businesses and collaborating as strategic partners, not just vendors. This approach can help suppliers secure valuable shelf space and grow sales with U.S. ag retailers.

items.title: A hidden tax deduction: How soil testing and planning can offset land-purchase costs
items.description: IRS Section 180 allows taxpayers who farm to immediately deduct expenditures for inputs including fertilizer and lime, rather than capitalizing them. The post A hidden tax deduction: How soil testing and planning can offset land-purchase costs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
By conducting soil testing and analysis, farmers can deduct the value of residual fertilizers and nutrients already present in the soil, effectively offsetting some of the land purchase costs.

Key points:
- IRS Section 180 allows farmers to immediately deduct expenses for fertilizers, lime, and soil conditioners rather than capitalizing them over time.
- Farmers can use this to deduct the value of excess nutrients in newly purchased land that were paid for by the previous owner.
- To qualify, farmers must have beneficial ownership of the land, conduct grid-based soil testing to assess fertility levels, and show the fertilizers are "exhausted" or used up.
- Working with agronomists, accountants, and real estate agents can help maximize these deductions.
- Soil testing should be done as close to the land purchase as possible to get the clearest picture of residual nutrients.
- The deductions can apply to both cropland and grassland, though grassland is a "gray area" requiring close work with a tax professional.
- Beyond the tax benefits, the soil testing provides valuable agronomic data to optimize future management and yields.

The article quotes several experts, including Kendall Koehn of Heartland Soil Services, Keaton Dugan of Pinion, and Nathan Woydziak of Crop Quest, providing insights on the process and requirements.

Overall, the article presents a potential "hidden tax deduction" that farmers can leverage when purchasing new land, helping to offset a major capital expense through careful soil analysis and tax planning.

items.title: USMCA fuels rural America‚Äôs economy
items.description: New analysis shows ag exports to Canada and Mexico generated $149B in economic output and supported nearly 500K jobs.
items.summary:
The new United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has fueled the rural American economy, according to a recent analysis. Key findings:

- Ag exports to Canada and Mexico generated $149 billion in economic output in 2020.
- These exports supported nearly 500,000 jobs across the U.S. 
- The top 5 states that benefited most were Iowa, Texas, California, Nebraska, and Illinois.
- Exports to Canada and Mexico accounted for 28.7% of total U.S. agricultural exports in 2020.
- The USMCA eliminated tariffs on nearly all agricultural products traded between the 3 countries.
- It also strengthened rules around biotechnology, geographical indications, and sanitary/phytosanitary measures.

These findings highlight the importance of trade agreements like the USMCA for supporting agricultural economies and jobs in rural America. Farmers and farm organizations should continue advocating for policies that maintain and expand access to the Canadian and Mexican markets.

items.title: The wind really does stress us out
items.description: Darla Tyler-McSherry of Ask In Earnest discusses how the wind really can wear us down, physically and mentally, why farmers and ranchers are particularly at risk, and what we can do about it.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Strong, persistent winds can negatively impact mental health by disrupting serotonin levels and increasing positive ions in the air, leading to increased anxiety, irritability, migraines, depression, and decreased cognitive function.

- Chinook winds, Zonda winds, Foehn winds, and Sirocco winds are regional examples of these types of disruptive winds experienced around the world.

- In Montana, the lack of snow cover and moisture due to the "open" winter is a major concern for farmers and ranchers as they worry about the health of fall-planted crops and preparation for spring planting.

- Recommended strategies to cope with the mental stress of persistent winds include using white noise, securing loose items, practicing box breathing, and reaching out to others for support.

- Resources available include Farm Aid, the AgriStress HelpLine, the National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, and local providers like clergy, pharmacists, and mental health professionals.

The article emphasizes that while the wind is unavoidable, suffering in silence is not, and farmers and ranchers can utilize various methods and resources to navigate the mental and physical challenges posed by persistent winds.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Louis Trevino and his partner Vincent are Ohlone from the East Bay region and are dedicated to preserving their people's culture and traditions.
- The Ohlone community faced significant harm and displacement over centuries due to Spanish colonization and the California mission system.
- Vincent is working to reclaim Ohlone lands, restore native plants and foods, and revive traditional cultural practices like basket-weaving and storytelling.
- The Sogorea Te' Land Trust, co-founded by Vincent, has secured the return of 5 acres of land in Vallejo, California for the Ohlone community.
- The trust aims to eventually acquire 500 acres of land to support Ohlone food production, housing, and cultural activities.
- Ohlone culinary traditions, including the use of acorns, bay laurel, and other indigenous ingredients, are being revived through community gatherings and educational programs.
- The efforts are not only preserving Ohlone heritage but also providing economic opportunities and food sovereignty for the community.

items.title: Pittsburgh Arcade Collective breathes life back into retired Catholic church
items.description: A former Duquesne Catholic church finds new life as a community arcade, blending historic architecture with pinball, classic games and shared play. The post Pittsburgh Arcade Collective breathes life back into retired Catholic church appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The group of local arcade and pinball enthusiasts purchased the church in March 2025 for $95,000.

The church, built in 1899, features sandstone bricks, stained glass windows, and high ceilings over 60 feet tall. After removing the pews, the large sanctuary space was well-suited to house the collective's growing collection of arcade cabinets, with the building's accessibility and existing infrastructure making it an ideal location.

The collective, which started as a loose network in 2021, previously had to store and transport their machines for the annual Pittsburgh Gaming Expo. Now, with a permanent home, they can keep the games set up year-round and host regular events like tournaments, community days, and all-you-can-play sessions.

The arcade, dubbed the "Church Arcade," features a mix of retro video games and pinball machines spanning decades, including some classic multiplayer cabinets. While the religious iconography was removed, many of the church's original architectural details remain, blending the historic building with the modern arcade experience.

The project has been generally well-received by the Duquesne community, with neighbors expressing excitement about the new local attraction. However, some former parishioners have mixed feelings due to the personal memories tied to the church. The collective aims to be sensitive to the building's history while creating new community-focused experiences.

The arcade's founders, Mike Hough and Jon Snow, hope the Church Arcade will become a hub for local events and a destination that brings people together, similar to the church's original purpose. They see the project as a continuation of the building's role as a community anchor.

items.title: SDSU Extension invites public to 2026 SD Grasslands Summit
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äî South Dakota State University Extension is inviting everyone interested in grasslands to attend the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell. Building on the momentum of its successful inaugural...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. SDSU Extension is hosting the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell, SD. The theme is "Grasslands: South Dakota's Most Valuable Resource".

2. Registration is $75 per person, but producers, volunteers, and individuals not attending on behalf of an employer can use the promo code "grasslandvoice" to register for free.

3. The 2-day event will feature:
   - Sessions on March 3 exploring how grasslands intersect with livestock, tourism, beekeeping, water quality, and cultural connections
   - Optional activities including a film festival and a session on collaboration between conservation districts and the SD Grasslands Initiative
   - A landowner/operator panel on March 4 discussing grassland restoration approaches and resources
   - Inspiring stories and facilitated conversations on next steps and opportunities for action
   - An afternoon Heritage Fund Forum highlighting funding models from neighboring states and conservation funding needs in SD

4. The South Dakota Grassland Coalition, SDSU Extension, and other partners helped shape the grassland initiative movement, which includes the inaugural 2024 South Dakota Grasslands Summit attended by over 200 participants.

items.title: SDSU Extension 4-H excels at 2026 Western National Roundup
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äì South Dakota State University Extension 4-H youth excelled at the 2026 Western National Roundup, winning the overall high state award in the Horse Classic. In the Horse Classic, states can compete in...
items.summary:
SDSU Extension 4-H youth excelled at the 2026 Western National Roundup, winning the overall high state award in the Horse Classic competition. 

In the Horse Classic, states can compete in hippology, horse (quiz) bowl, public speaking, and judging. SDSU Extension 4-H had an impressive showing, winning:
- 2nd place in hippology and horse quiz bowl
- 3rd place in horse judging
- Individual placings:
  - Lila Stutzman (Bon Homme County) - 1st in horse quiz bowl
  - Arryanna Schnetzer (Bon Homme County) - 4th in horse quiz bowl
  - Delaney Zoss (Sanborn County) - 3rd in hippology
  - Hayden Talsma (Bon Homme County) - 4th in hippology
  - Tarynn Torsney (Bon Homme County) - 6th in horse judging
  - Hope Baysinger (Sanborn County) - 5th in public speaking

The SDSU Extension 4-H livestock judging team placed 16th overall. 

The Western National Roundup is an annual contest held in Denver, Colorado that brings together 4-H and FFA youth from across the nation to compete, learn, and connect. Youth must qualify at the state level to compete.

The SDSU Extension 4-H coaches highlighted the hard work and dedication of the team members throughout the year in preparing for the competition.

items.title: Dedicated educators help South Dakota youth succeed nationally
items.description: In May, South Dakota sent 84 youth to the National Land and Range Judging Contest in El Reno, Oklahoma. Out of the 34 states that competed, only Texas came close to matching those numbers with...
items.summary:
In May 2026, South Dakota sent 84 youth to the National Land and Range Judging Contest in El Reno, Oklahoma, the most of any state (Texas was second with 72 participants). 

The competitions test students' knowledge of range plants, land management, and soil types. To qualify, students must first compete at the state level. The article notes this is a testament to the passionate group of teachers, coaches, and mentors in South Dakota who work hard to prepare the students. 

Experts like SDSU Extension Interim Director Sandy Smart and agriculture teacher Brady Duxbury emphasize the extensive work required, as students need to identify and memorize details about 130 different plants. However, they say it is rewarding to see the students' growth through the process.

Other major national contests for South Dakota 4-H and FFA youth include the Western National Roundup, North American International Livestock Expo, Family and Consumer Science National Championship, and 4-H Shooting Sports National Championships.

items.title: Pine Needles: Another Possible Threat to Beef Cow Pregnancies
items.description: Seasoned cow-calf producers know the long list of everything that has to go right for a cow to become pregnant during breeding season. Nutrition, as measured by cow body condition, needs to be right. The...
items.summary:
Key points:

- Ponderosa pine trees, common in the Black Hills region of South Dakota, contain a compound called isocupressic acid that can interfere with hormones like progesterone and cause abortions in pregnant cows.

- Cattle typically won't consume pine needles when they have ample access to more typical feed. But during cold winter weather and deep snow, cows may start eating fallen pine needles under trees, often coinciding with the last trimester of gestation when the fetus is most susceptible.

- Studies have shown that once gestation reaches 42 days, herd pregnancy loss is usually only around 2% at most. However, sporadic late-term pregnancy losses can occur, and in rare cases, exposure to a toxin like pine needles can cause large-scale pregnancy losses.

- Other pine tree species besides Ponderosa can also pose this threat. The issue has been recognized for at least the past 50 years in cattle production.

- Cattle producers in less mountainous areas may be less familiar with this potential threat to beef cow pregnancies.
