items.title: Texas cool-season vegetable growers navigate weather, market challenges
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 10, 2026 The post Texas cool-season vegetable growers navigate weather, market challenges appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Irrigation shortages and persistent drought are impacting cool-season crop production. Acreage for vegetable crops in the Valley dipped slightly due to irrigation concerns, as water sources from the Rio Grande River are at critical levels.

- In the Winter Garden region, recent freezing temperatures damaged spinach fields nearing harvest, though younger spinach and onions appear unaffected. Growers continue to endure extreme drought, with some wells not producing water.

- In the Rio Grande Valley, onions are the primary cool-season crop, with around 7,000 of the 15,000-18,000 horticultural crop acres planted with onions. Overall vegetable prices in the Valley have been lower than previous years.

- Vegetable growers in the Valley continue to express concerns about irrigation allotments needed for warm-season crops and citrus orchards, as water levels at key reservoirs remain critically low. 

- The expected 202,000 acre-feet water delivery from Mexico on December 15 has still not been received.

- Beyond water issues, the article also discusses crop conditions and livestock impacts across various Texas regions, including the Panhandle, South Plains, Rolling Plains, North, East, Far West, and West Central.

The article provides a comprehensive overview of the weather, water, market, and production challenges facing Texas cool-season vegetable growers, with detailed information on key statistics, locations, and expert insights.

items.title: FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative
items.description: February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is reassessing the safety of a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. Under the reassessment, announced Tuesday, the agency will look into the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a chemical that health advocates have raised concerns about […] The post FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA is reassessing the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. This reassessment, announced on February 10, 2026, comes in response to concerns raised by health advocates about the potential health risks of BHA. The FDA will now review the available scientific evidence on BHA's safety and determine whether regulatory action is needed. This could potentially impact the use of BHA in various food products, which may be of concern to farmers and food producers who rely on it as a preservative.

items.title: Gob Bless Johnstown: Annual Gob Fest celebrates western Pa. dessert
items.description: The Johnstown Galleria hosted its annual Gob Fest on Jan. 31 where vendors sold thousands of gobs, a western Pennsylvania cake-like sandwich dessert. The post Gob Bless Johnstown: Annual Gob Fest celebrates western Pa. dessert appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
On January 31, 2026, thousands of locals flocked to the Johnstown Galleria mall for the event. Over 20 vendors, including bakeries, fire stations, and churches, sold over 4,000 gobs in dozens of flavors like chocolate, Oreo, cherry, and pistachio. Top sellers were Kinsey's Kookies and More, which sold 3,000 gobs, and Judy's Sweet Treats, which baked 1,050 gobs and won the "best flavor" award ($250 prize). The FARM BBQ and Bakery won "best overall gob" ($250).

The gob's origins trace back to the 1920s at the Harris-Boyer bakery in Johnstown, which trademarked the term in 1927. The treat became a local staple, with over 150,000 sold monthly in the 1960s. Theories on the gob's name include connections to sailors or coal miners. Amish women in eastern PA are also credited with inventing similar "whoopie pies" by using up excess cake batter.

For many attendees, the Gob Fest evokes fond memories and family traditions. Longtime vendor Judy Cooper learned to make gobs from her mother, while attendee Sam Uzelac recalled his mother sending him gobs while in the military. The Galleria's owner, Leo Karruli, hopes to continue the 20-year-old festival to support local businesses and preserve the region's gob legacy.

items.title: Why did soybeans grab double-digit gains today?
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Corn prices were also slightly firm on Tuesday.
items.summary:
The February WASDE report is expected to be a "maintenance" report, without significant changes compared to previous editions. Key highlights:

- The report will be released on February 9th, 2023.
- It is typically a less eventful edition, serving as preparation for the March report which will include updated planting data.
- USDA is not anticipated to make major revisions to 2022/23 crop production or supply/demand forecasts.
- However, analysts will be closely watching for any changes to U.S. corn and soybean ending stocks estimates.
- Current USDA forecasts show U.S. corn ending stocks at 1.257 billion bushels and soybean ending stocks at 225 million bushels.
- Farmers and industry experts will analyze the report for potential market impacts and guidance on spring planting decisions.

items.title: Ag groups urge U.S., Mexico and Canada leaders to move forward with USMCA
items.description: The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA released the results of an economic analysis that shows significant growth in the value of U.S. ag exports to Canada and Mexico since USMCA was enacted.
items.summary:
S., Canada, and Mexico to renew and further strengthen the USMCA trade agreement. 

The coalition's analysis found that since the USMCA was enacted in 2020:
- U.S. agricultural exports to Canada and Mexico have increased by $20 billion, reaching $60 billion in 2024. This represents 47% growth, far outpacing the 18% increase to the rest of the world.
- The USMCA has generated $149 billion in total economic contribution to the U.S. economy and supported nearly 500,000 jobs and $36 billion in wages.
- For every $1 in ag exports under USMCA, another $2.45 of economic activity was supported, contributing $64 billion to U.S. GDP and $13 billion in tax revenue.

The USMCA must undergo a formal review by July 2026 to determine whether to renew the agreement for another 16 years. Failure to renew would lead to the agreement's expiration in 2036.

While the coalition sees USMCA as positive overall, they note issues that need to be addressed, including:
- Canada's management of dairy tariff-rate quotas
- Mexico not fully implementing commitments on preserving common cheese names
- The need for clearer rules on agricultural biotech and more access for U.S. ethanol in Mexico

Experts warn that without USMCA, the U.S. farm economy would face greater instability in an already challenging environment.

items.title: Integrating sustainability, circularity, and One Health in pork production systems
items.description: LIVE STREAM TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17 AT 1 PM CT - Dr. Gerald Shurson shares insight why sustainability, One Health and circularity practices must be part of pork production.
items.summary: The webinar will discuss the importance of integrating sustainability, circularity, and One Health principles in pork production systems. Dr. Gerald Shurson, a professor at the University of Minnesota, will provide insights on why these practices are crucial. The webinar will be live-streamed on Tuesday, February 17 at 1 PM CT. Key topics will include reducing environmental impact, utilizing waste streams, and promoting animal, human, and ecosystem health in pork production. Farmers and industry stakeholders are encouraged to tune in to learn about practical ways to enhance the sustainability and resilience of pork operations.

items.title: WASDE Lifts Livestock Prices Amid Shifting Supply Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report points to tighter dynamics and stronger prices across [...]
items.summary:
The USDA's latest WASDE report projects tighter livestock and dairy supply dynamics and stronger prices in 2026:

- Beef production is revised higher due to increased slaughter of steers, heifers, and cows, as well as slightly heavier dressed weights. While the 2025 calf crop was smaller, USDA expects more cattle outside feedlots to be available for placement early in 2026.

- Pork production is also raised on higher slaughter levels and modestly heavier weights in the first half of 2026. 

- In contrast, broiler and turkey production forecasts were lowered for early 2026 due to recent hatchery data and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza-related culling, tightening poultry and egg supplies.

- Beef imports were raised on strong demand for lean processing beef, while pork exports increased on improved competitiveness.

- Fed-cattle and hog prices were raised across all quarters, and the all-milk price is lifted to $18.95 per hundredweight.

The report indicates resilient livestock demand, even as disease and herd shifts reshape 2026 supply expectations. Farmers can expect higher prices across much of the livestock and dairy complex.

items.title: WASDE Leaves Soybeans Steady, Boosts Corn Exports Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report left much of the 2025/26 outlook unchanged but [...]
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- USDA's latest WASDE report left soybean supply and use forecasts unchanged, with the season-average farm price staying at $10.20 per bushel. Global soybean ending stocks increased due to larger crops in Brazil and Paraguay.

- For corn, USDA raised U.S. exports by 100 million bushels to 3.3 billion, citing strong sales and inspections, and cut ending stocks to 2.1 billion bushels. The season-average corn price remained at $4.10 per bushel.

- U.S. wheat ending stocks increased to 931 million bushels on lower food use, keeping prices at $4.90 per bushel.

- Cotton saw slightly weaker demand, with exports trimmed and the projected farm price lowered to 60 cents per pound.

- Overall, strong corn exports offer support, while soybeans and wheat remain weighed down by ample global supplies.

items.title: Farmers face greater risk with planting insurance option removed
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs Risk Management Agency announced last fall that it was eliminating the extra coverage option for prevented planting insurance.
items.summary:
North Dakota farmers will face greater risk this year as the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Risk Management Agency has eliminated the extra "buy-up" coverage option for prevented planting insurance. 

From 2010 to 2024, the extra prevented planting coverage led to $3.18 billion in payments for North Dakota producers, more than any other state. This option allowed farmers to insure against years when weather prevents them from planting a crop.

Without this option in 2026, North Dakota farmers like Justin Quandt, who farms near Oakes, will have less protection against wet spring conditions that can leave some of their fields unplantable. Quandt's family normally invests in the additional prevented planting coverage, which requires insuring all acres in a county.

The North Dakota Farmers Union president Matt Perdue said the agency's decision is disappointing, as the recent farm bill had expanded federal crop insurance in other ways. However, an NDSU study concluded that the improvements will not outweigh the loss of the extra prevented planting coverage for North Dakota.

Senators, including John Hoeven of North Dakota, have asked the USDA to undo the prevented planting changes for 2027 and beyond "to help provide a layer of certainty when disasters beyond their control render them unable to plant a crop." 

Farmers face a March 15 deadline to make 2026 crop insurance purchases. Insurance agent Bethany Rentz hopes the USDA will bring back the extra prevented planting coverage based on pushback from other affected states.

items.title: Larger Operating Loans Drive Farm Lending Growth
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farm lending activity strengthened in 2025 as producers relied more heavily on [...]
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farm lending activity strengthened in 2025, driven by a sharp increase in the size and volume of non-real-estate farm loans, particularly operating loans.

- The volume of new operating loans rose nearly 40% year-over-year in Q4 2025 and averaged over 20% growth across 2025.

- Inflation-adjusted operating loan sizes were about 30% larger than the previous year, reflecting elevated input costs and expanded financing needs.

- Increased feeder cattle lending also contributed to stronger loan demand.

- Average maturities for operating loans increased by roughly 3 months from 2024 and reached record highs late in the year. Machinery and equipment loan maturities also lengthened.

- Interest rates on non-real-estate loans declined for the 6th straight quarter, with larger loans seeing greater reductions. Over 80% of operating loans carried variable rates.

- Bigger operating loans are helping farms manage costs, but also signal growing reliance on borrowed capital.

items.title: Ocean Freight Risks Remain Despite Lower Average Rates
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Ocean freight rates averaged lower in 2025, but the year underscored how [...]
items.summary:
While early-year rate declines were driven by seasonal slowdowns and ample vessel supply, global commodity flows later tightened vessel availability and lifted freight costs. Disruptions like low water levels on Argentina's Parana River and pre-holiday shipping demand in Asia pushed 4th quarter 2025 rates higher compared to earlier in the year.

The article notes that external factors like weather, river conditions, and non-grain commodity demand can rapidly affect shipping costs that ultimately impact farmers. While fleet growth in 2026 could limit sustained freight rate spikes, unexpected demand shifts or logistical constraints remain wildcards. The USDA warns that transportation risk has not disappeared, only changed form, despite the lower annual freight rate average.

The key numbers and statistics from the article include:
- Ocean freight rates averaged lower in 2025
- Late-summer and fall 2025 saw disruptions that highlighted lingering vulnerability in global logistics
- 4th quarter 2025 freight rates remained elevated compared to earlier in the year

The article does not mention any specific names of people, organizations or programs. The locations referenced are Nashville, TN and Argentina's Parana River.

The context and causes behind the freight rate dynamics were the seasonal slowdowns, ample vessel supply, weaker dry bulk demand, increased global commodity flows, and external factors like weather and river conditions. The impacts for farmers are that they will continue to absorb sudden increases in shipping costs despite overall favorable annual freight rate averages.

The article does not provide any expert quotes or specific recommendations/action items for farmers.

items.title: Export Inspections Stay Firm For Corn, Soybeans, Wheat
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – U.S. grain export inspections remained solid during the week ending February 5, [...]
items.summary:
Export Inspections Remain Strong for Corn, Soybeans, and Wheat:

- During the week ending February 5, 2026, U.S. grain export inspections were solid:
  - Corn inspections totaled 51.5 million bushels, up from the prior week and well above the same period last year. Marketing-year-to-date corn inspections stand near 1.34 billion bushels, running sharply ahead of last year's pace.
  - Soybean inspections reached 41.7 million bushels, slightly below the previous week, but cumulative soybean inspections are holding near 850 million bushels for the marketing year. China remained a notable buyer.
  - Wheat inspections totaled 21.3 million bushels, nearly matching last year's level. Year-to-date wheat inspections are now near 637 million bushels, continuing to outpace last season.
  - Sorghum inspections came in at 4.9 million bushels, with most shipments moving through the Gulf. China was again a primary destination.

- The strong export inspections provide continued demand support across key commodities, with corn leading the gains and China active in soybeans and sorghum.

items.title: Soybean-based tires put Ohio sheriff‚Äôs departments on patrol
items.description: The Ohio Soybean Council is donating Goodyear tires made with soybean oil to all 88 county sheriff‚Äôs departments. The post Soybean-based tires put Ohio sheriff‚Äôs departments on patrol appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Ohio Soybean Council has launched a program to donate a set of Goodyear tires containing soybean oil in the tread compound to each of the 88 county sheriff's departments across Ohio. This tire donation highlights the innovative uses of soybeans and their co-products in everyday products, and demonstrates the council's support for local law enforcement.

Through the "Patrol With Soy" program, each county will receive a set of Goodyear Eagle Enforcer All Weather tires, made with soybean oil in the tire tread compound, which provides year-round, pursuit-rated performance. The use of soybean oil instead of petroleum-based oils improves cold-weather flexibility and provides better traction in wet and snowy conditions.

The tire donation program will be ongoing over the next 2-3 years, until all 88 counties receive their donation. So far, tires have been donated to Crawford, Darke, Henry, Marion, Paulding, Ross, Seneca, Van Wert, and Wood Counties.

The program is a partnership between the Ohio Soybean Council and Goodyear, and it aims to showcase the different ways soybean oil is being used in products, as well as support the first responders in the communities where Ohio's soybean farmers live and work. The Ohio Soybean Council highlights that this partnership creates demand for the almost 5 million acres of soybeans planted in the state each year.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
In this episode of Minnesota CropCast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interview Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist. Dr. Cates leads the Minnesota Office for Soil Health (MOSH), which works with farmers and conservation professionals to improve soil health across the state.

Dr. Cates, who has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, discusses the partnership between MOSH and the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR). They collaborate to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs) to promote the adoption of conservation practices and cover crops by farmers.

The episode also highlights an upcoming intensive educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy, which will help farmers learn about the benefits and implementation of cover cropping. 

Farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops is a key focus area for MOSH and its partners. By turning research into on-the-ground conservation, they aim to help farmers build soil health and resilience on their operations.

items.title: AgriLife Extension shares cotton jassid guidance for green industry
items.description: Fact sheet targets invasive insect threat to Texas‚Äô ornamental, nursery industry The post AgriLife Extension shares cotton jassid guidance for green industry appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service and Research are providing guidance to the Texas ornamental nursery industry on the two-spot cotton leafhopper, also known as the cotton jassid, which is a new invasive pest that threatens the industry and future cotton production.

Key points:
- Texas A&M experts have developed a fact sheet with identification, biology, and management information for the cotton jassid to help ornamental producers.
- The experts have also produced training videos for Texas Department of Agriculture inspectors and green industry growers/professionals.
- They are working closely with the Texas Department of Agriculture and USDA to assess the pest's potential for establishment in Texas.
- The cotton jassid has a wide host range, so prevention and management will require a collaborative, holistic approach.
- Growers are encouraged to contact AgriLife Extension for identification, monitoring, and science-based management strategies.
- AgriLife Extension is working on a grant proposal for research to better understand and control the pest, and establish economic thresholds for ornamental crop losses.
- The goal is to help the ornamental industry mitigate the potential impact of this invasive pest and prevent its spread to cotton fields.

items.title: USDA completes screwworm sterilization facility in Texas
items.description: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced the completion of a sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. The post USDA completes screwworm sterilization facility in Texas appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The USDA has completed a new sterile fly dispersal facility in Edinburg, Texas. This facility will expand the USDA's ability to disperse up to 300 million sterile flies per week along the U.S.-Mexico border by the end of 2027, if necessary, to combat the spread of New World Screwworm (NWS). 

The facility was a high priority project completed in record time by the Trump Administration. It is part of a five-pronged plan announced by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins in June 2025 to enhance the USDA's ability to detect, control, and eliminate NWS.

The USDA currently produces sterile flies for dispersal at the COPEG facility in Panama and is investing $21 million to support Mexico's renovation of an existing fruit fly facility in Metapa, which will double NWS production capacity by summer 2026. Once all facilities are operational, the USDA will have the capacity to disperse up to 500 million sterile flies per week to fight the spread of this pest.

While there have been no NWS detections inside the U.S., the USDA is asking Americans to remain vigilant in checking their livestock and pets for signs of the pest, and to immediately report any suspected cases to state or USDA officials.

items.title: Purdue invents wireless sensor to monitor subsoil health
items.description: Purdue researchers developed HARVEST, a wireless passive sensor system that monitors subsoil conditions to help farmers use water and more efficiently. The post Purdue invents wireless sensor to monitor subsoil health appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Purdue University researchers have developed a wireless sensor system called HARVEST that can monitor subsoil health using low-cost, unmanned aerial vehicle platforms. The system employs nail-shaped sensing probes that are wirelessly connected to a triple-ring antenna above the ground, allowing for passive and distributed monitoring of key parameters like moisture and salinity within the subsoil.

The HARVEST system is designed to be scalable and cost-effective, making it accessible for both small, independent farmers and large commercial operations. It was tested in a research cornfield at Purdue's Agronomy Center for Research and Education throughout a full growing season.

The invention addresses the need for efficient use of water, fertilizers, and pesticides, as applying uniform amounts across large fields can lead to significant waste. By providing deeper insights into subsoil conditions, HARVEST enables data-driven agricultural management that can reduce environmental impact, improve crop yields, and lower operational costs.

The research team, led by Purdue associate professor Rahim Rahimi, hopes to see HARVEST sensors deployed at scale, working in tandem with smart tractors, irrigation systems, and decision-support software to play a key role in reducing unnecessary input use, lowering costs, protecting ecosystems, and improving food security globally.

items.title: Animal care isn‚Äôt always what people think
items.description: It‚Äôs a misconception that farmers don‚Äôt care about their animals. They absolutely do, it just shows up in different ways than it does for pets. The post Animal care isn‚Äôt always what people think appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Livestock animals are not pets and cannot be treated the same way. They are raised in groups, not individually, and their care practices are designed for the good of the herd.

- Certain care practices like hoof trimming, dehorning, sheep shearing, and castrating may look harsh but are done to help the animals' health and safety in the long run.

- Livestock animals do not bond with people like pets do. Farmers and ranchers know their animals and can notice when something is off, seeking veterinary attention as needed.

- Animal diets are specially formulated for their stage of life, and consistency is key for good results and optimal health.

- Animal agriculture is continuously improving animal welfare and handling practices, with farmers certified in animal welfare and quality assurance programs.

- The distinction between livestock and pets is important, as the type of care that works for pets would not work for farm animals.

No specific numbers, dates, or names were provided in the article summary.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports
items.description: February 9, 2025 ‚Äì The United States has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country, acting on plans floated in October that received pushback from U.S. cattle producers. On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by […] The post Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country. On February 9, 2025, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by an unspecified amount. This move received pushback from U.S. cattle producers when the plans were first floated in October. The increased beef imports from Argentina are part of the executive order signed by President Trump.

items.title: EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage
items.description: ‚ÄúThe Trump administration‚Äôs hostility to farmers and rural America knows no bounds,‚Äù Bill Freese, science director at the Center for Food Safety (CFS), said in a press release. ‚ÄúDicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities.‚Äù Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues emerged about a decade ago, when it […] The post EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reapproved the use of the weedkiller dicamba despite ongoing concerns about crop damage from dicamba drift. Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues with dicamba drift and crop damage have emerged over the past decade. The Center for Food Safety (CFS) has criticized the decision, stating that "dicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities." The reapproval is part of the Trump administration's policies, which the CFS has described as "hostility to farmers and rural America." The EPA's decision allows the continued use of dicamba on genetically engineered, dicamba-tolerant soybeans and cotton.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary: The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) is returning on March 10-11, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program, costing $60, will cover topics like irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement with proof of attendance and adoption of a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on-farm. The event is organized by the University of Minnesota Extension.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Over 80% of the world's flowering plants rely on pollinators to reproduce, and pollinators provide an estimated $200 billion in ecological services annually.

There are around 20,000 species of bees globally, with over 500 species found in Minnesota alone. Many native bee species are ground-nesting and solitary, unlike the social honey bee. Bee populations are declining due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease.

Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is critical. Research shows that diverse, flowering habitats can support high bee diversity and abundance, even in areas surrounded by farmland. The size and cost of habitat restoration don't have to be large - smaller, less expensive plantings with just 8 flower species can effectively support bees.

Pollinator habitats don't increase pest problems in adjacent crop fields, and can actually boost yields of self-pollinating crops like soybeans by up to 20% through improved pollination. Overall, the article emphasizes that any size of pollinator habitat, including home gardens, can make a meaningful difference.

The article cites research from the University of Minnesota Bee Lab and other sources. It includes comments from Dr. Dan Cariveau, an Associate Professor at the Bee Lab. The article was published on February 9, 2026.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. Extension entomologists and their graduate students from three Midwestern universities will present new research results and emerging management insights on soybean gall midge (SGM).

The webinar will cover the following topics:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, including cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) CEUs by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. Growers, crop consultants and scouts, educators, and industry representatives are encouraged to attend.

items.title: New field ecologist provides rainfall, land use and biodiversity expertise
items.description: Felicity Newell brings global research experience to Texas landscapes The post New field ecologist provides rainfall, land use and biodiversity expertise appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Texas A&M AgriLife has hired Felicity Newell, Ph.D., a globally trained field ecologist, as an assistant professor to research biodiversity, land management, and ecosystem resilience.

- Newell has prior research experience at Louisiana State University, the Florida Museum of Natural History, and the University of Bern in Switzerland.

- Her research examines how ecological communities respond to variations in rainfall, hydrology, habitat structure, and land-use history, with a focus on oak ecosystems, fire management, and restoration.

- Newell plans to continue her work in the Andes and apply similar approaches in the diverse ecological gradients of Texas, from the Trans-Pecos to the Piney Woods.

- She will teach courses related to the fundamentals of ecology and how invertebrates influence vertebrates, disease dynamics, and ecosystem processes, aiming to provide students with direct field-based learning experiences.

- Newell's appointment emphasizes research while supporting undergraduate and graduate training, and she expects to collaborate with Texas A&M researchers in forest restoration, prescribed fire, hydrology, and biodiversity monitoring.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This allows for a head start on slower-growing and longer-maturing vegetables.

Herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary should be started in February, as they take 1-4 weeks to germinate. Tomatoes and peppers also benefit from an early February start, needing 80+ days to mature and 1 month to germinate, respectively. 

Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and kale thrive in cool spring weather and can be started in February. Lettuces grow quickly and can be directly sown outside under row cover. Carrots and parsnips, with their sensitive taproots, should be direct sown in their final location in February.

Onions and leeks also do well with a February sowing, taking 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to fully mature.

Key tips include using a heat mat for quick germination, protecting seedlings from late frosts, and transplanting or up-potting as needed. Farmers in warmer climates can choose faster-maturing brassica and pepper varieties.

The article emphasizes that February seed starting, combined with protective growing structures, allows farmers to get a head start on the season and maximize their yields of healthy, mature produce.

items.title: Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses
items.description: The man in the video spoke Saint Aubin’s native language, Haitian Creole, and said you didn‚Äôt need to speak English to work in JBS‚Äôs Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where wages were high. He suggested that upon arrival, your housing and other needs would be taken care of. Convinced, Saint Aubin traveled across the country […] The post Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Haitian immigrant Jean Saint Aubin was recruited to work at a JBS Swift Beef Co. packing plant, with promises of high wages and housing provided. 
- Saint Aubin and other workers have filed a lawsuit against JBS, alleging unsafe working conditions, wage theft, and threats of deportation.
- The lawsuit claims JBS exploits immigrant workers by subjecting them to dangerous conditions, forcing overtime without pay, and threatening deportation if they complain.
- Immigrant workers make up a significant portion of the U.S. food production workforce, despite increased federal immigration enforcement.
- Experts say food companies take advantage of immigrant workers' vulnerable legal status to mistreat them, as the workers fear retaliation or deportation if they speak up.
- The lawsuit seeks back pay, improved working conditions, and an end to the company's alleged abusive practices targeting immigrant employees.

items.title: Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift
items.description: Board of Regents approve renaming of Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center The post Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has approved the renaming of the Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center to the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Poultry Science Farm Complex. This change honors a generous gift from Barbara and William "Bill" Huffman '53.

The 16-acre complex, located in College Station, supports all aspects of poultry production and processing, including two classrooms. The Huffmans' investment strengthens the Department of Poultry Science's ability to prepare students, advance discovery, and serve the industries that feed the world.

Bill Huffman, who earned a bachelor's degree in poultry science from Texas A&M in 1953, has a longstanding devotion to the department. In 1952, he was a member of the Texas A&M Junior Poultry Judging Team that won the Junior National Poultry Judging Contest, and the highest scoring individual at the Senior National Poultry Judging Contest that same year.

The Huffmans' support for poultry science extends beyond the renamed complex. In 2020, they established the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Chair in Poultry Science, and previously donated funds for a trophy case in the Kleberg Animal and Food Sciences Center. They have also supported Texas A&M through contributions to scholarships, the Corps of Cadets, the Mays Business School, and the Bush School of Government and Public Service.

The renaming of the complex reflects both gratitude for past support and confidence in the future of poultry science at Texas A&M, as it represents the intersection of education, research, and real-world application.

items.title: Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia
items.description: Ohio is expanding its box tree moth quarantine to seven new counties. Learn how to identify this invasive pest, check the new boundaries, and report sightings. The post Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This is in addition to the existing quarantine in 7 other counties. The quarantine will allow the ODA to restrict the movement of boxwood shrubs and monitor the invasive pest. 

Box tree moths were first detected in Ohio in June 2023 near the Hamilton-Clermont county border. In 2025, the pest was found in Berkeley and Morgan counties in West Virginia, leading the USDA to establish a statewide quarantine there in December.

Box tree moths pose a threat to boxwood plants, which are an important part of Ohio's nursery industry. Residents are advised to check their boxwood for signs of infestation, such as chewed leaves, webbing, and caterpillars. Any sightings should be reported to the ODA or West Virginia Dept of Agriculture.

State and federal agencies will be conducting inspections and setting traps to monitor box tree moth populations in the quarantined areas. The quarantines are intended to stop the further spread of this invasive pest from East Asia.

items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Added 1,686 acres of habitat to wildlife areas, accepted 122 acres from The Nature Conservancy, and protected riparian habitat.
- The population of human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders surpassed 2,000 through partnerships with zoos and schools.
- Provided $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- Resolved an illegal taxidermy business case with $38,000 in restitution.
- Completed 4,800 acres of timber stand improvement, 6,000 acres of aerial herbicide spraying, and managed 9,420 acres of wetlands.
- Certified 208 adult 4-H shooting sports instructors and trained over 240 youth.
- Documented over 450 bee species, but 70 may be extirpated from the state.
- Stocked 2,000 juvenile lake sturgeon in the Cuyahoga River, 750 in the Sandusky River, and 3,000 in the Maumee River.
- Supported H2Ohio wetland restoration projects on 870 private acres and 6 additional sites.
- Studied wild turkey, gray fox, and black bear populations through banding, GPS collaring, and surveys.

2026 Initiatives:

- Conclude wild turkey nesting/survival study in 2026, continue monitoring into 2027.
- Launch voluntary outfitter accreditation program to improve reputation and communication.
- Re-launch Backyard for Wildlife program to help landowners create wildlife habitat.
- Continue Ohio Bear Project to study black bear status.
- Launch Sauger Restoration Plan to reestablish natural reproduction in the Maumee and Sandusky rivers.
- Replace 2 aging aircraft with a new P68C plane for law enforcement and wildlife management.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are now using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now attention time - whether a farmer stays engaged and explores more content.

AgWeb.com recently redesigned to increase user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in mobile users reading more articles per visit

These deeper engagement metrics are more valuable to advertisers, as they signal real interest and create stronger opportunities for brand messaging to be seen and remembered. 

The article notes that in a typical visit, readers only absorb about 28% of page text, so simplifying layouts and guiding deeper engagement is key.

For advertisers, high-attention environments like the redesigned AgWeb deliver stronger brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness. This creates more value through more time with content, more exposure opportunities per session, and better alignment with how farmers search today.

The article concludes that if the goal is to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments, AgWeb offers one of the most effective digital environments in agriculture, as better attention leads directly to better outcomes.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The goal was to determine if growers can maintain productivity and profitability while using reduced tillage and cover crops to protect the soil.

The study compared 4 management systems: conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% but did not affect final yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across locations, with no significant differences between tillage systems. 
- When accounting for operational costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest net return due to cover crop management costs.
- The project will continue in 2026 to track longer-term soil and soybean responses in the conservation systems.

The article includes:
- Locations of trials in Illinois and Iowa
- Cereal rye management details (40-50 lb/ac, 1000-1200 lb/ac biomass)
- Soybean planting details (30-in rows, 140,000-150,000 seeds/ac)
- Figures showing soybean growth, leaf nutrient levels, and yield distributions
- Table of estimated costs, revenue, and partial net return for each system

Overall, the results suggest that reduced tillage and cereal rye cover crops can maintain soybean yields compared to conventional tillage, although profitability may be impacted by the higher management costs. Further research is underway to understand longer-term implications.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
It covers different types of greenhouses and their characteristics, as well as specific crops that can be started early in a greenhouse environment.

Key points:
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher than outside. They need ventilation.
- Low tunnels and cold frames can also provide 5-15¬∞F of extra warmth.
- Fully fortified designer greenhouses with climate control allow year-round growing.
- Good crops to start in a February greenhouse include tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (kale, cabbage, cauliflower), lettuces, potatoes, and flowers.
- Greenhouse growing helps get a head start on spring crops, protects plants from pests/diseases, and allows for extended growing seasons.
- Key factors are providing consistent warmth, moisture, and light for the crops.

The article does not mention any specific people, organizations, or dates/deadlines. It focuses on general greenhouse growing techniques and recommended crops for a February greenhouse setup.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, available through the ISU Extension Store, are intended to provide Iowans with the basic understanding of effective pesticide use and the information needed to successfully pass the revised certification exams. The updated Iowa Core Manual (CS445) is now available for purchase, and new exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. Additionally, the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1) now includes a two-page informational update, which is provided in each manual, and all private exams now include content from this insert. For more information, contact Betsy Danielson, an extension specialist for Iowa State University Extension and Outreach in the Pesticide Safety Education Program (PSEP).

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer chosen shape not only the quantity of leads captured, but also their quality and purchase-readiness.
- Shifting the mindset from what the business wants to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial.
- Designing the right offer that solves a specific farmer problem or need is more effective than just chasing leads.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, dates/deadlines, names of people/organizations/programs, locations, or expert quotes. The overall recommendation is for businesses to focus on creating valuable offers that meet farmers' needs, rather than just trying to collect as many leads as possible.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The way farmers find information has fundamentally changed, with more time spent on AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews, rather than traditional search engines.
- Brands need to evolve their marketing strategies to be present in these new discovery channels, or risk becoming invisible to their audience.
- At Farm Journal, they are observing this shift in real-time and recommend that all ag marketers reevaluate their 2026 strategies.
- The focus should be on an answer-driven content strategy and amplifying trusted voices, rather than just optimizing for traditional SEO.
- Discoverability is now about winning citations, brand mentions, and trusted source references that build authority, even in "zero-click" moments.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, dates, or quotes from experts. It is focused on the broad shift in agricultural marketing and the need for brands to adapt to the changing landscape.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This approach originated in Brazil's tropical rainforests and can be a good option for farmers with forested land.

Forest farming involves thinning out a forest to create the optimal conditions for growing crops in the understory, such as native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops. It can also involve practices like silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching) and alley cropping (growing crops between rows of trees).

Key benefits of forest farming include:
- Improved water and soil quality
- Carbon sequestration (up to 22 lbs per year in first 20 years)
- Habitat for beneficial insects, birds, mammals, fungi, and bacteria
- Opportunities to grow specialty crops like mushrooms, ramps, syrups, and edible roots

The best candidates for forest farming are farms that already have forested areas or riparian zones with trees. It can be done on a small scale to provide cover for sensitive crops. Farmers should consult their agricultural extension office to develop a forest management plan.

There are also considerations around regulations, especially for wild plants, and the need to be proactive about marketing and selling forest-grown products through avenues like online sales, pick-your-own, and agritourism.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
1. Clarify Objectives: Spray drones can be useful for making applications on wet soils, applying to tall crops, reducing compaction, targeted applications, and supplementing existing spraying capacity.

2. Regulatory Considerations: Farmers need an FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing. Only products labeled for aerial use can be applied.

3. Insurance and Risk Management: Farmers need specific coverage for chemical liability, general liability, and drone/equipment damage. Most standard policies do not cover these.

4. Equipment Selection: Consider tank capacity, battery life, nozzle/atomizer options, GPS guidance, and local support when choosing a spray drone system.

5. Training and Safe Operation: Proper training is essential, including gaining flight experience, calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.

6. Gradual Adoption: Start on a small scale, compare to conventional methods, and develop efficient procedures before expanding use.

7. Iowa-Based Resources: ISU Extension, Digital Ag Innovation Lab, licensed dealers, and IDALS can provide guidance and support.

8. Future Developments: Ongoing improvements in payload, automation, and integration with precision ag data will shape the long-term role of spray drones.

The article recommends a thoughtful, step-by-step approach to spray drone adoption to ensure compliance, safety, and effective integration into Iowa farming operations.

items.title: Double-crop Soybean Management Practices – Project Report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction There is a growing interest in wheat/soybean double-cropping systems in Illinois, extending into parts of central Illinois where wheat acreage has been limited in recent decades. USDA-NASS survey estimates that 60-80% of Illinois wheat acres are double-cropped with soybeans. Implementing this system in central and northern Illinois has been constrained primarily by low wheat acreage and by later wheat harvest, which often delay
items.summary:
Summary of the Agricultural News Article:

The article reports on a 2-year field trial conducted near Hammond in Piatt County, Illinois to evaluate the effects of soybean maturity group (MG), seeding rate, and starter fertilizer on double-crop soybean yields.

Key Findings:
- Double-crop soybean yields averaged 55.7 bushels/acre in 2024 and 47.8 bushels/acre in 2025.
- Full-season soybean varieties (MG 3.6-3.8) yielded about 4% (2.1 bushels/acre) more than early-maturing varieties (MG 3.0-3.2).
- Yield response to seeding rate differed by maturity group: Early-maturing varieties reached maximum yield (52.3 bu/acre) at 252,000 seeds/acre, while full-season varieties reached maximum yield (53.4 bu/acre) at 207,000 seeds/acre.
- Starter fertilizer (26 lb N, 11 lb S) increased yields by 1.4 bushels/acre (2.6%) in 2024 but had no impact in 2025.

The trials were conducted by the University of Illinois Department of Crop Sciences in collaboration with the Illinois Agricultural Experiment Station, Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, and a local producer. Similar trials across more locations are ongoing to strengthen regional recommendations.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
This protects the seeds while allowing them to be exposed to the cold, moist conditions needed to break dormancy. The result is hardier transplants that mature faster than usual.

Vegetables recommended for winter sowing include:
- Cabbages (standard, Napa, and early-maturing 'Carex' varieties)
- Spinach ('Avon' and 'Space' are good options)
- Onions (long-day, short-day, or intermediate-day varieties depending on latitude) 
- Leafy greens like kale, collards, chard, watercress, and microgreens

Flowers recommended for winter sowing include:
- Pansies
- Echinacea
- Snapdragons (4 groups for different climate conditions)
- Larkspur
- Scabiosa

These plants are well-suited for winter sowing as they can handle cold temperatures and often require a period of cold stratification to germinate properly. Planting them this way gives farmers a head start on the growing season.

The article emphasizes that winter sowing is a great way for farmers to maximize profits and productivity in the spring. It provides detailed advice on selecting the right plants, understanding their growth requirements, and leveraging winter sowing to get a jump on the season.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Prairie Strips - Planting 10-25% of land with prairie strips can attract beneficial predators, improve soil nutrients, and boost yields by attracting pollinators. This increases biodiversity above and below ground.

2. Low Tilling - Reducing tillage and using cover crops can improve soil structure and increase biodiversity of insects and other organisms. This supports both crops and wildlife.

3. Regenerative Grazing - Using rotational grazing, planting native species, and managing invasives can improve pasture health and provide better habitat for local wildlife compared to non-native forage.

4. Integrated Pest Management - Attracting beneficial insects through diverse plantings and cultural practices can reduce reliance on harmful pesticides that kill off habitat.

5. Conservation Easements - Partnering with land trusts to establish conservation easements can protect natural resources and provide tax benefits for farmers with large landholdings.

The article states these strategies can directly correlate to higher soil health, increased biodiversity above and below ground, and better support for multiple species. Implementing even 10-25% of the land in these practices can make a big impact. Experts emphasize farming should work with the natural world instead of against it for long-term sustainability.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. Each meeting will feature topics tailored to local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.

Topics will include crop market and climate outlooks for 2026, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots/drones.

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting. Late or on-site registration is $100. Registration includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available for a $30 fee.

The meetings are designed to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

"Our goal is always to prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers," said Josh Michel, field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach.

Registration and more information is available on the Crop Advantage Series registration site. Contacts for questions are crops@iastate.edu and regional ISU Extension and Outreach field agronomists.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The finalists are:

- Alsum Farms (Friesland, WI) - A multigenerational, 3,600-acre operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops with a vertically integrated business model.

- Dalton Farms (Wakeman, OH) - A 7th-generation, 2,000-acre corn/soybean farm with a 400-head cattle herd and on-farm market selling local meats and maple syrup.

- Splitter Farms (Sterling, KS) - A 1,400-acre owned, 18,500-acre total row crop operation using data-driven management after the owner's father passed away in 2010.

The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, TN on February 9-11. The $10,000 Next Generation Award will go to Tim Nuss (El Dorado Hills/Lodi, CA) for his diversified farming and ag tech entrepreneurship. The $5,000 Women in Agriculture Award will be awarded to Helle Ruddenklau (Amity, OR) for her leadership in Oregon's agriculture industry. The awards are sponsored by BASF, Fendt, Pioneer, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Still an opportunity to attend the ICM Conference!
items.description: This year we are offering on-site registration for the Integrated Crop Managem
items.summary: The Iowa State University Integrated Crop Management (ICM) Conference will be held on December 10-11, 2025 at the Meadows Events and Conference Center in Altoona, IA. The conference will feature 33 workshops covering topics like crops, pests, nutrient management, and conservation. Attendees can earn up to 14 continuing education credits for Certified Crop Advisers, as well as Iowa Commercial Pesticide Applicator continuing instruction for 2025 in categories 1A, 1B, 1C, and 4 for an additional fee. Invited speakers will discuss topics related to the Endangered Species Act, the timing of corn and soybean planting, and integrated pest management for corn leafhopper and corn stunt disease. On-site registration is available for this premier crop management conference. The article was written by Meaghan Anderson, a field agronomist serving nine counties in central Iowa and an extension specialist with Iowa State University Extension and Outreach.

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop compared to corn. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant, has lower nitrogen requirements, and is not susceptible to the tar spot pathogen. Experts will discuss sorghum's production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Speakers will include:
- Mitch Tuinstra, Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue, who will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.
- Brad Shelton, FPAC superintendent
- Jason Tower, Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent
- Nick Minton, Purdue Extension beef systems specialist
- Jeff Jackson, Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist

The event will include venue tours, a dinner, and a bull test station tour. Those with questions or accessibility needs can contact Keith Johnson, Purdue professor of agronomy.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024, with the Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer rising 8 points to 113.

- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

- Despite declines in corn (11%) and soybean (5%) prices, farmers reported fewer worsened conditions compared to a year ago and fewer expected negative future outcomes.

- The top concerns for farmers were high input costs (34%) and the risk of lower crop/livestock prices (29%).

- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points to 81, reflecting worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points to 38, but remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as 75% still believe it's a bad time for large investments.

- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118, while the Long-Term index dropped 6 points to 146.

- 72% of crop farmers expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same in 2025 compared to 2024.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assessing the emerging tar spot disease in corn. The disease, which had been endemic in several Latin American countries since 1904, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada.

The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology at Purdue, is using a mix of statistical analysis, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision to better understand the dynamics of tar spot in corn. Their work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

The researchers are collaborating with colleagues in Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S. to address biosecurity challenges and provide rapid and accurate information to stakeholders. They have developed a digital method for quantifying tar spot in corn, which they have tested under field conditions against human raters.

Another research effort involves the laboratory of Purdue's Mohammad Jahanshahi, who has adapted his AI and computer-vision approaches from monitoring civil infrastructure to inspecting and analyzing agricultural disease epidemiology. Mariela Fern√°ndez-Campos, a PhD student, and Abhishek Subedi, a PhD student in civil engineering, are working on a proof-of-concept data fusion project that integrates drone imagery and weather data to capture crucial details about the tar spot pathosystem.

The team aims to quantify and model tar spot severity by referencing and integrating imagery with spatial and temporal data, ultimately providing farmers with rapid and accurate information about the disease.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The new UW Madison publication "Potassium Cycle" provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The 2-page publication outlines key potassium concepts, including:

- Potassium is an essential nutrient for plant growth and development, playing a role in photosynthesis, drought resistance, and overall plant health.
- Potassium enters the soil through weathering of minerals, organic matter decomposition, and fertilizer application. It is taken up by crops, can leach, and is also removed in harvested products.
- Optimal potassium levels in soil are 100-200 ppm. Deficient levels can reduce yields, while excess potassium can antagonize other nutrient uptake.
- Soil testing is recommended to determine potassium needs. Fertilizer application rates should be based on crop removal and soil test results.
- Cover cropping, manure application, and reducing tillage can help retain potassium in the soil system.

The publication is available free of charge from the UW Madison Nutrient and Pest Management (NPM) program. Farmers are encouraged to review the resource to better understand the potassium cycle and optimize potassium management for their operations.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary: The 2023 Wisconsin winter wheat crop is developing 10-14 days ahead of average due to the warm weather. As of mid-April, 80% of the state's winter wheat was in the jointing stage, compared to the typical 50-60% at this time. However, the advanced growth stage increases the risk of frost damage. Farmers are advised to closely monitor their fields and consider frost protection measures if temperatures drop below 24¬∞F. Despite the early progress, overall winter wheat condition in Wisconsin is reported as 72% good to excellent, slightly lower than the 5-year average of 75%. Experts recommend that farmers scout fields regularly, apply fungicides proactively, and stay up-to-date on the latest weather forecasts to manage the 2023 winter wheat crop effectively.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Key points:

- Soybean plant stands can be reduced early in the season due to abiotic factors (freezing, hail, flooding) or biotic factors (slugs, deer, disease, insects).
- The optimal plant population for soybeans is 100,000-150,000 plants per acre. Stands below 80,000 plants per acre may warrant replanting.
- Factors to evaluate include current plant population, growth stage, growing conditions, and expected yield of the current stand vs. a replanted crop.
- Replanting should be done within 7-10 days of the initial planting to maximize yield potential. Later replanting can result in up to 10% yield reduction.
- Replanting expenses include seed, fuel, labor, and potential crop insurance implications. Weighing costs vs. expected yield increase is important.
- Shawn P. Conley, a soybean and small grains specialist at UW-Madison, advises carefully evaluating the field before making a replanting decision.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:

- 2,4-D may be used for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans, but there are important considerations for farmers to be aware of.
- The EPA approved the registration of 2,4-D for use on Enlist E3 soybeans, but this approval expires on December 20, 2023. Farmers need to be aware of this deadline.
- Rodrigo Werle, a weed scientist and extension specialist at UW-Madison, recommends that farmers consult with their local extension office or chemical dealer to ensure they are using 2,4-D products in compliance with the label and relevant regulations.
- Werle also advises farmers to be cautious of potential off-target movement of 2,4-D, which can damage nearby susceptible crops. He recommends following all label instructions carefully.
- The article does not provide any specific data or statistics, but emphasizes the importance of staying informed and compliant when using 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybeans in 2024.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
The Wisconsin Certified Crop Advisor (CCA) Board election results are as follows:

Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the Wisconsin CCA Board. The election process was overseen by the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

The newly elected board members will serve 3-year terms. Their responsibilities will include providing guidance and support to Wisconsin's network of over 1,000 CCAs, who play a crucial role in promoting sustainable agriculture practices.

CCAs are agricultural professionals certified by the American Society of Agronomy to provide expert advice to farmers on topics like nutrient management, pest control, and crop production. There are currently over 13,000 CCAs across the United States and Canada.

The Wisconsin CCA program is funded in part by the Wisconsin Corn Promotion Board and the Wisconsin Soybean Marketing Board. These organizations represent the state's corn and soybean farmers respectively.
